qas.question: What method did Muslim scientists use more than the Greeks?
What book did Ibn al-Haytham write?
What law did the Persians know of?

answers.text: The law of refraction of light

qas.question: What theory did Ibn al-Haytham have proof for?

context: Muslim scientists placed far greater emphasis on <a0_0>experiment<a0_0/> than had the Greeks. This led to an early scientific method being developed in the Muslim world, where significant progress in methodology was made, beginning with the experiments of Ibn al-Haytham (Alhazen) on optics from c. 1000, in his <a1_0>Book of Optics<a1_0/>. <a2_0>The law of refraction of light<a2_0/> was known to the Persians. The most important development of the scientific method was the use of experiments to distinguish between competing scientific theories set within a generally empirical orientation, which began among Muslim scientists. Ibn al-Haytham is also regarded as <a3_0>the father of optics<a3_0/>, especially for his empirical proof of <a4_0>the intromission theory of light<a4_0/>. Some have also described Ibn al-Haytham as the "first scientist" for his development of the modern scientific method.
